result.execSummary:
Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Hannah Lynn Klingensmith

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: Defendant Hannah Lynn Klingensmith in court with attorney Mary L.R. Burns.  Charles James Simono appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Called at 3:18 PM. Also called 15CM128. Burns - resolved. State 15CM80 - DRI only count in this case. Court explains what it means to be DRI, Klingensmith undertands and Court dismisses and reads in case. On 15CM128 - plead to both counts as alleged, withhold sentence and place on probation for 18 months with conditions of: court costs on each count, AODA and follow, employment/school, no alcohol or entry into any bars or taverns, 30 hours of community service. Burns and Kligensmith agree. Kligensmith pleads NC to both counts as alleged on 15CM128. Court has plea questionnaire, goes thru it, finds the defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived her constitutional rights by entering her plea and right to JT, accepts plea, adjudges guilty, proceed to sentencing. State - follow joint recommendation. Burns - follow joint recommendation - asks if defendant can petition for early release of probation after 1 year, 3 days jail credit only if revoked, requests expungement. State has no objections to the early release from probation but will not agree with it either, believes it is a DOC decision. Court agrees. Klingensmith withholds comment. Court sentences the defendant to the following: on each count - withhold sentence and place on probation for 18 months - concurrent to each other, with conditions of: court costs on each count - paid thru probation, AODA and follow, maintain/obtain full time employment/school, no consumption or possession of alcohol and no entry into any bars or taverns except for purposes of assiting/visiting her grandmother that owns a bar, 30 hours of community service total, submit DNA sample and expungment information given, credit for 3 days only if revoked, authorize expungement under 973.015 if probation is completely satisfied, right to appeal, adjourned.
State's Motion and Order for Adjournment

Defendant Hannah Lynn Klingensmith in court with attorney Mary L.R. Burns.  Charles James Simono appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Called at 2:54 PM. Burns - not resolved - set for JT, has gone over Frye with the defendant. State puts offer on record - amend to county ordinance violdation of DC with a fine of $300.00 plus costs. Off record for Burns to explain both offer and ramifications of rejecting the offer. Court continues bond, explains ramifications of rejecting offer, Court will not accept another offer of amending to ordinance, Burns and defendant understand, set for JT.  Jury trial scheduled for August 10, 2015 at 08:30 am.

Defendant Hannah Lynn Klingensmith in court with attorney Mary L.R. Burns.   Charles Simono appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Called at 9:00 AM. Burns has complaint, waives reading, enters NG plea. Court accepts plea and sets for FPT. Burns asks for signature bond for stated reasons. State - no objections. Court - bond - $300 signature bond, refund bond to poster.  Final pre-trial scheduled for July 8, 2015 at 01:45 pm.
Bonded out prior to probable cause.
